core.persona: You are an expert literary analyst specializing in character relationships and narrative structure.

working.current_chapter_text:
CHAPTER VII

The rustle of a woman’s dress was heard in the next room. Prince
Andrew shook himself as if waking up, and his face assumed the look it
had had in Anna Pávlovna’s drawing room. Pierre removed his feet from
the sofa. The princess came in. She had changed her gown for a house
dress as fresh and elegant as the other. Prince Andrew rose and politely
placed a chair for her.

“How is it,” she began, as usual in French, settling down briskly
and fussily in the easy chair, “how is it Annette never got married?
How stupid you men all are not to have married her! Excuse me for saying
so, but you have no sense about women. What an argumentative fellow you
are, Monsieur Pierre!”

“And I am still arguing with your husband. I can’t understand why he
wants to go to the war,” replied Pierre, addressing the princess
with none of the embarrassment so commonly shown by young men in their
intercourse with young women.

The princess started. Evidently Pierre’s words touched her to the
quick.

“Ah, that is just what I tell him!” said she. “I don’t
understand it; I don’t in the least understand why men can’t live
without wars. How is it that we women don’t want anything of the kind,
don’t need it? Now you shall judge between us. I always tell him: Here
he is Uncle’s aide-de-camp, a most brilliant position. He is so
well known, so much appreciated by everyone. The other day at the
Apráksins’ I heard a lady asking, ‘Is that the famous Prince
Andrew?’ I did indeed.” She laughed. “He is so well received
everywhere. He might easily become aide-de-camp to the Emperor. You know
the Emperor spoke to him most graciously. Annette and I were speaking of
how to arrange it. What do you think?”

Pierre looked at his friend and, noticing that he did not like the
conversation, gave no reply.

“When are you starting?” he asked.

“Oh, don’t speak of his going, don’t! I won’t hear it spoken
of,” said the princess in the same petulantly playful tone in which
she had spoken to Hippolyte in the drawing room and which was so plainly
ill-suited to the family circle of which Pierre was almost a member.
“Today when I remembered that all these delightful associations
must be broken off ... and then you know, André...” (she looked
significantly at her husband) “I’m afraid, I’m afraid!” she
whispered, and a shudder ran down her back.

Her husband looked at her as if surprised to notice that someone besides
Pierre and himself was in the room, and addressed her in a tone of
frigid politeness.

“What is it you are afraid of, Lise? I don’t understand,” said he.

“There, what egotists men all are: all, all egotists! Just for a whim
of his own, goodness only knows why, he leaves me and locks me up alone
in the country.”

“With my father and sister, remember,” said Prince Andrew gently.

“Alone all the same, without my friends.... And he expects me not to
be afraid.”

Her tone was now querulous and her lip drawn up, giving her not a
joyful, but an animal, squirrel-like expression. She paused as if she
felt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre, though the
gist of the matter lay in that.

“I still can’t understand what you are afraid of,” said Prince
Andrew slowly, not taking his eyes off his wife.

The princess blushed, and raised her arms with a gesture of despair.

“No, Andrew, I must say you have changed. Oh, how you have....”

“Your doctor tells you to go to bed earlier,” said Prince Andrew.
“You had better go.”

The princess said nothing, but suddenly her short downy lip quivered.
Prince Andrew rose, shrugged his shoulders, and walked about the room.

Pierre looked over his spectacles with naïve surprise, now at him and
now at her, moved as if about to rise too, but changed his mind.

“Why should I mind Monsieur Pierre being here?” exclaimed the little
princess suddenly, her pretty face all at once distorted by a tearful
grimace. “I have long wanted to ask you, Andrew, why you have changed
so to me? What have I done to you? You are going to the war and have no
pity for me. Why is it?”

“Lise!” was all Prince Andrew said. But that one word expressed
an entreaty, a threat, and above all conviction that she would herself
regret her words. But she went on hurriedly:

“You treat me like an invalid or a child. I see it all! Did you behave
like that six months ago?”

“Lise, I beg you to desist,” said Prince Andrew still more
emphatically.

Pierre, who had been growing more and more agitated as he listened to
all this, rose and approached the princess. He seemed unable to bear the
sight of tears and was ready to cry himself.

“Calm yourself, Princess! It seems so to you because.... I assure you
I myself have experienced ... and so ... because ... No, excuse me!
An outsider is out of place here.... No, don’t distress yourself....
Good-by!”

Prince Andrew caught him by the hand.

“No, wait, Pierre! The princess is too kind to wish to deprive me of
the pleasure of spending the evening with you.”

“No, he thinks only of himself,” muttered the princess without
restraining her angry tears.

“Lise!” said Prince Andrew dryly, raising his voice to the pitch
which indicates that patience is exhausted.

Suddenly the angry, squirrel-like expression of the princess’ pretty
face changed into a winning and piteous look of fear. Her beautiful eyes
glanced askance at her husband’s face, and her own assumed the timid,
deprecating expression of a dog when it rapidly but feebly wags its
drooping tail.

“Mon Dieu, mon Dieu!” she muttered, and lifting her dress with one
hand she went up to her husband and kissed him on the forehead.

“Good night, Lise,” said he, rising and courteously kissing her hand
as he would have done to a stranger.

workflow.goal: Analyze 'War and Peace' to extract characters, relationships, and significant events.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER III
chapter_summaries.summary: Anna Pávlovna organizes her guests into three distinct groups to facilitate conversation. The primary focus is on the Vicomte de Mortemart, whom Anna 'serves up' as a storyteller to discuss the murder of the Duc d’Enghien. Hélène Kurágina and Lise Bolkónskaya join this circle, while Prince Hippolyte Kurágin is introduced as Hélène's physically similar but intellectually inferior brother.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew Bolkónski arrives at the soirée, displaying a weary and bored demeanor toward high society and his wife, Lise. He reveals he is departing for war as an aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov. Pierre Bezúkhov shows great affection for Andrew, and they agree to meet for supper. Meanwhile, Prince Vasíli and Hélène depart, but not before Princess Drubetskáya entreats Vasíli to use his influence to secure a military appointment for her son, Borís.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER V
chapter_summaries.summary: The conversation at Anna Pávlovna's soirée turns to Napoleon's recent actions in Italy and the execution of the Duc d’Enghien. Pierre Bezúkhov shocks the aristocratic guests by defending Napoleon's actions as political necessities for the general good, while Prince Andrew supports Pierre's logic despite his own cynical outlook. The hostess, Anna Pávlovna, attempts to steer the conversation away from Pierre's controversial and socially inappropriate defense of the Revolution.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VI
chapter_summaries.summary: As the soiree concludes, Pierre's social awkwardness is highlighted, though Anna Pávlovna offers him a mild, conditional forgiveness. Prince Hippolyte flirtatiously attends to Princess Lise, much to the indifference of Prince Andrew. Anna Pávlovna and Lise finalize a plan to match Anatole Kurágin with Andrew's sister. The chapter ends with Pierre and Andrew arriving at Andrew's home, where they begin a private discussion about Pierre's future and the political ideas discussed at the party.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VII
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew, Pierre, and Princess Lise Bolkónskaya converse in Andrew's study. Lise expresses her fear and resentment regarding Andrew's departure for the war, accusing him of being an egotist and changing toward her. The interaction reveals a deep marital strain, with Andrew treating her with cold, formal politeness while Pierre watches with awkward discomfort. The chapter ends with Lise's emotional outburst subsiding into a piteous submission before she retires for the night.

05d36871-2501-4fad-95b8-b375384f7650.description: A 40-year-old maid of honor to Empress Márya Fëdorovna, characterized by her social enthusiasm and political fervor.
05d36871-2501-4fad-95b8-b375384f7650.identity: Hostess and social gatekeeper of Petersburg society.
current_goals: Host a successful reception
Promote support for the war against Napoleon
Ensure all guests follow the protocol of greeting her aunt
Manage the social reputation of her salon
05d36871-2501-4fad-95b8-b375384f7650.evolution_summary:
A 40-year-old maid of honor to Empress Márya Fëdorovna, characterized by her social enthusiasm and political fervor.
Introduced as a high-society hostess who uses her 'enthusiasm' as a social vocation to influence court opinion.
She is shown to be highly sensitive to social hierarchy, treating guests differently based on their status and showing visible distress when etiquette is breached.
05d36871-2501-4fad-95b8-b375384f7650.last_known_location: Anna Pávlovna's drawing room, St. Petersburg

1d1ea9ad-587d-4cc3-bbb7-d7888f42ae71.description: An elderly, influential courtier with a serene, flat face and a habit of speaking with indifferent irony.
1d1ea9ad-587d-4cc3-bbb7-d7888f42ae71.identity: A pragmatic courtier who manages his social capital carefully.
current_goals: Attend social functions
Maintain his status at court
Attend the ambassador’s entertainment
Maintain social connections
Leave the party for the ambassador's fete
Avoid overextending his political favors
1d1ea9ad-587d-4cc3-bbb7-d7888f42ae71.evolution_summary:
An elderly, influential courtier with a serene, flat face and a habit of speaking with indifferent irony.
Introduced as a seasoned courtier who navigates social circles with practiced indifference and refined manners.
His role as a father is introduced, showing him as part of a larger family unit within the Petersburg elite.
His pragmatic approach to social influence is highlighted, as is his susceptibility to guilt regarding past debts.
1d1ea9ad-587d-4cc3-bbb7-d7888f42ae71.last_known_location: The anteroom of Anna Pávlovna's house

1b3b757c-1a83-443d-9b89-b768c0804f4b.description: The beautiful daughter of Prince Vasíli and a maid of honor.
1b3b757c-1a83-443d-9b89-b768c0804f4b.identity: The stunningly beautiful and socially poised daughter of Prince Vasíli.
current_goals: Maintain her social position as a center of admiration
1b3b757c-1a83-443d-9b89-b768c0804f4b.evolution_summary:
The beautiful daughter of Prince Vasíli and a maid of honor.
Hélène is depicted as a masterpiece of social grace, moving with a 'victorious beauty' that commands the room's attention.

88cbe937-5f37-4903-91c1-c6821b89b5d8.description: The pregnant wife of Prince Bolkónski, highly charming and popular in society.
88cbe937-5f37-4903-91c1-c6821b89b5d8.identity: The pregnant, socially-dependent wife of Prince Andrew.
current_goals: Facilitate the match between Anatole and her sister-in-law
Enjoy the upcoming ball
Persuade Andrew not to leave her
Express her resentment at being sent to the country
88cbe937-5f37-4903-91c1-c6821b89b5d8.evolution_summary:
The pregnant wife of Prince Bolkónski, highly charming and popular in society.
Lise is shown to be an active participant in Anna Pávlovna's social engineering, contrasting with her husband's detachment.
Lise shifts from a charming socialite to a vulnerable, frightened wife who feels abandoned by her husband's lack of pity and his 'changed' attitude.

aac39302-17d1-4dfe-a248-92ca1e3e22a0.identity: A socially eccentric man who uses gravity to mask his lack of depth.
current_goals: Participate in the social circle
Attend to Princess Bolkónskaya
Entertain the little princess with heraldry
aac39302-17d1-4dfe-a248-92ca1e3e22a0.evolution_summary:
The son of Prince Vasíli.
Hippolyte is introduced as a foil to his sister Hélène, possessing her features but none of her charm or intellect.
Hippolyte continues to act as a comic or absurd relief, tracing coats of arms on tables while serious political debates occur.

42367a83-661b-44d3-9912-682f58053860.description: Illegitimate son of Count Bezúkhov; socially awkward and observant.
42367a83-661b-44d3-9912-682f58053860.identity: A sensitive and socially awkward observer of high-society domestic life.
current_goals: Navigate his first appearance in society
Discuss intellectual topics like the Abbé Morio's scheme
Maintain his friendship with Prince Andrew
Navigate the 'great world' of society
Defend the ideals of the French Revolution
Justify Napoleon's actions to the Russian aristocracy
Decide between becoming a guardsman or a diplomatist
Maintain his friendship with Andrew
Avoid being caught in the middle of a marital dispute
42367a83-661b-44d3-9912-682f58053860.evolution_summary:
Illegitimate son of Count Bezúkhov; socially awkward and observant.
Introduced as a 'stout' and 'heavily built' young man whose naturalness and lack of artifice make him a disruptive force in the rigid salon environment.
His deep admiration for Prince Andrew is revealed, showing he has a loyal and emotional nature despite his social clumsiness.
Pierre transitions from being merely socially awkward to being a source of genuine political scandal in the salon by defending Napoleon's most controversial acts.
Pierre's physical clumsiness and social ineptitude are fully displayed, yet his essential 'kindly' nature earns him a reprieve from Anna Pávlovna.
Pierre's role as an 'outsider' is emphasized as he witnesses the private dysfunction of the Bolkónski marriage, showing his inability to handle emotional confrontation.

c7478c00-c2c0-46cb-8888-b9a0fc8bc2d9.description: A man with a scheme for perpetual peace.
c7478c00-c2c0-46cb-8888-b9a0fc8bc2d9.identity: A man with a scheme for perpetual peace.
c7478c00-c2c0-46cb-8888-b9a0fc8bc2d9.evolution_summary: A man with a scheme for perpetual peace.

36114f3f-d6fe-4530-9cd2-072ec87436dc.description: A French emigrant and storyteller at Anna Pavlovna's soirée, regarded as a social 'morsel' by the hostess.
36114f3f-d6fe-4530-9cd2-072ec87436dc.identity: A French emigrant and storyteller at Anna Pavlovna's soirée, regarded as a social 'morsel' by the hostess.
36114f3f-d6fe-4530-9cd2-072ec87436dc.evolution_summary: A French emigrant and storyteller at Anna Pavlovna's soirée, regarded as a social 'morsel' by the hostess.

4c270c64-9fbc-4702-aef6-76da440daf4e.description: A disillusioned aristocrat and husband to Lise Bolkónskaya, departing for the war against Napoleon.
4c270c64-9fbc-4702-aef6-76da440daf4e.identity: A disillusioned aristocrat and soldier who is emotionally detached from his domestic life.
current_goals: Leave for the war to escape the tedium of Petersburg society
Serve as aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov
Challenge the Vicomte's royalist rhetoric
Support Pierre's logical arguments
Prepare for his departure to war
Guide Pierre toward a career decision
Escape the domestic sphere for the war
Maintain social decorum despite marital strife
4c270c64-9fbc-4702-aef6-76da440daf4e.evolution_summary:
A disillusioned aristocrat and husband to Lise Bolkónskaya, departing for the war against Napoleon.
Introduced as a man deeply bored by his social environment and his wife, seeking purpose in military service.
Andrew shows a willingness to support Pierre's unpopular views, highlighting his disdain for the superficiality of the other guests.
Andrew's duality is shown: he is cold and 'disagreeable' to Hippolyte but 'gentle and affectionate' toward Pierre.
Andrew's boredom with society is revealed to extend to his marriage; he treats his wife with a coldness that borders on cruelty, prioritizing his military ambitions over her emotional needs.

994186aa-8b48-4928-ab04-7b509d637a53.description: A poor but well-born woman dedicated to advancing her son's career through social influence.
994186aa-8b48-4928-ab04-7b509d637a53.identity: A poor but well-born woman dedicated to advancing her son's career through social influence.
994186aa-8b48-4928-ab04-7b509d637a53.evolution_summary: A poor but well-born woman dedicated to advancing her son's career through social influence.

a01b82de-7c90-4d20-9948-3d6b0999d7ac.description: The son of Princess Drubetskáya, for whom she is seeking a transfer to the Guards.
a01b82de-7c90-4d20-9948-3d6b0999d7ac.identity: The son of Princess Drubetskáya, for whom she is seeking a transfer to the Guards.
a01b82de-7c90-4d20-9948-3d6b0999d7ac.evolution_summary: The son of Princess Drubetskáya, for whom she is seeking a transfer to the Guards.

214e601f-fce1-427d-9d54-fd55e64b518b.description: The son of Prince Vasíli, proposed as a suitor for Prince Andrew's sister.
214e601f-fce1-427d-9d54-fd55e64b518b.identity: The son of Prince Vasíli, proposed as a suitor for Prince Andrew's sister.
214e601f-fce1-427d-9d54-fd55e64b518b.evolution_summary: The son of Prince Vasíli, proposed as a suitor for Prince Andrew's sister.

interactions.reasoning: They interact with the familiarity of long-time social acquaintances, though their temperaments differ.
interactions.context: Prince Vasíli is the first guest to arrive at Anna's reception.

evidence.quote: I will have nothing more to do with you and you are no longer my friend, no longer my ‘faithful slave,’ as you call yourself!

interactions.causal_reasoning: Establishes the social dynamic and political tension that will drive the evening's conversations.

interactions.reasoning: Pierre's radical political views cause Anna Pávlovna extreme distress and social embarrassment.
interactions.context: Pierre defends the execution of the Duc d’Enghien and Napoleon's rise to power.

evidence.quote: “Dieu! Mon Dieu!” muttered Anna Pávlovna in a terrified whisper.

interactions.causal_reasoning: Pierre's refusal to adhere to salon etiquette establishes him as a disruptive element in Anna's circle.

interactions.reasoning: Anna Pávlovna forgives his social blunders on the condition that he changes his radical opinions.
interactions.context: Pierre is leaving the party after his controversial defense of Napoleon.

evidence.quote: “I hope to see you again, but I also hope you will change your opinions, my dear Monsieur Pierre.”

interactions.causal_reasoning: This interaction softens the immediate social antagonism from Chapter 5, moving it toward a mentor-pupil or gatekeeper-outcast dynamic.

interactions.reasoning: They are secretly coordinating a marriage between Anatole Kurágin and Andrew's sister.
interactions.context: A low-toned conversation in the hall during departure.

evidence.quote: Anna Pávlovna had already managed to speak to Lise about the match she contemplated between Anatole and the little princess’ sister-in-law.

interactions.causal_reasoning: Initiates a major subplot regarding the Kurágin and Bolkónski families.

interactions.causal_reasoning: Creates a social debt that Prince Vasíli feels compelled to honor despite his desire to economize his influence.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna Schérer hosts a high-society reception in St. Petersburg.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna Pávlovna Schérer... greeting Prince Vasíli Kurágin, a man of high rank and importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna expresses her intense hatred for Napoleon and her faith in Emperor Alexander.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that Antichrist—I really believe he is Antichrist—I will have nothing more to do with you

event_chronicle.description: Pierre Bezúkhov arrives at the reception, causing social discomfort.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Anna Pávlovna’s alarm was justified, for Pierre turned away from the aunt without waiting to hear her speech about Her Majesty’s health.

event_chronicle.description: Princess Bolkónskaya discusses her husband's departure for the war.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “You know,” said the princess... “my husband is deserting me? He is going to get himself killed. Tell me what this wretched war is for?”

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna gathers a group to hear the Vicomte de Mortemart's account of the Duc d’Enghien's death.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Anna Pávlovna arranged a group round him, inviting everyone to listen to his tale.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Hippolyte Kurágin is introduced to the circle, displaying his lack of wit and awkward social presence.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: His face on the contrary was dulled by imbecility and a constant expression of sullen self-confidence

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew Bolkónski announces he is going to war as an aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: General Kutúzov... has been pleased to take me as an aide-de-camp....

event_chronicle.description: Princess Drubetskáya successfully pressures Prince Vasíli into promising to help her son Borís.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: But in Princess Drubetskáya’s case he felt, after her second appeal, something like qualms of conscience.

event_chronicle.description: Pierre Bezúkhov publicly defends Napoleon's execution of the Duc d’Enghien as a political necessity.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “The execution of the Duc d’Enghien,” declared Monsieur Pierre, “was a political necessity, and it seems to me that Napoleon showed greatness of soul by not fearing to take on himself the whole responsibility of that deed.”

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna attempts to silence Pierre by inviting him to another table, which he ignores.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Won’t you come over to the other table?” suggested Anna Pávlovna. But Pierre continued his speech without heeding her.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna and Lise Bolkónskaya agree to pursue a marriage match between Anatole Kurágin and Andrew's sister.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I rely on you, my dear,” said Anna Pávlovna, also in a low tone. “Write to her and let me know how her father looks at the matter.”

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew and Pierre leave the soiree together to continue their conversation at Andrew's home.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I am expecting you, Pierre,” said the same voice, but gently and affectionately.

event_chronicle.description: Lise Bolkónskaya confronts Prince Andrew about his coldness and his decision to leave her for the war.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Just for a whim of his own, goodness only knows why, he leaves me and locks me up alone in the country.”

event_chronicle.description: Lise reveals her pregnancy as a source of her fear, though she finds it 'indecorous' to speak of it directly before Pierre.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: She paused as if she felt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre, though the gist of the matter lay in that.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER I
chapter_summaries.summary: In July 1805, Anna Pávlovna Schérer, a maid of honor to the Empress, hosts a reception in St. Petersburg. She greets Prince Vasíli Kurágin with a passionate political tirade against Napoleon (Buonaparte) and the state of European politics. They discuss the impending war, the role of Emperor Alexander, and the arrival of guests including the Vicomte de Mortemart and Abbé Morio.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER II
chapter_summaries.summary: Anna Pávlovna’s reception continues as more members of Petersburg high society arrive, including Prince Vasíli’s children, Hélène and Hippolyte, and the pregnant Princess Bolkónskaya. The social atmosphere is defined by rigid etiquette, specifically the mandatory greeting of Anna's aunt. Pierre Bezúkhov, the illegitimate son of a dying grandee, makes a socially awkward entrance, causing anxiety for the hostess due to his lack of conformity to courtly manners.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER III
chapter_summaries.summary: Anna Pávlovna organizes her guests into three distinct groups to facilitate conversation. The primary focus is on the Vicomte de Mortemart, whom Anna 'serves up' as a storyteller to discuss the murder of the Duc d’Enghien. Hélène Kurágina and Lise Bolkónskaya join this circle, while Prince Hippolyte Kurágin is introduced as Hélène's physically similar but intellectually inferior brother.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew Bolkónski arrives at the soirée, displaying a weary and bored demeanor toward high society and his wife, Lise. He reveals he is departing for war as an aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov. Pierre Bezúkhov shows great affection for Andrew, and they agree to meet for supper. Meanwhile, Prince Vasíli and Hélène depart, but not before Princess Drubetskáya entreats Vasíli to use his influence to secure a military appointment for her son, Borís.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER V
chapter_summaries.summary: The conversation at Anna Pávlovna's soirée turns to Napoleon's recent actions in Italy and the execution of the Duc d’Enghien. Pierre Bezúkhov shocks the aristocratic guests by defending Napoleon's actions as political necessities for the general good, while Prince Andrew supports Pierre's logic despite his own cynical outlook. The hostess, Anna Pávlovna, attempts to steer the conversation away from Pierre's controversial and socially inappropriate defense of the Revolution.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VI
chapter_summaries.summary: As the soiree concludes, Pierre's social awkwardness is highlighted, though Anna Pávlovna offers him a mild, conditional forgiveness. Prince Hippolyte flirtatiously attends to Princess Lise, much to the indifference of Prince Andrew. Anna Pávlovna and Lise finalize a plan to match Anatole Kurágin with Andrew's sister. The chapter ends with Pierre and Andrew arriving at Andrew's home, where they begin a private discussion about Pierre's future and the political ideas discussed at the party.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VII
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew, Pierre, and Princess Lise Bolkónskaya converse in Andrew's study. Lise expresses her fear and resentment regarding Andrew's departure for the war, accusing him of being an egotist and changing toward her. The interaction reveals a deep marital strain, with Andrew treating her with cold, formal politeness while Pierre watches with awkward discomfort. The chapter ends with Lise's emotional outburst subsiding into a piteous submission before she retires for the night.
